questions.text: Which of the following represents the action of superior oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
The actions of superior oblique muscle include depression and intortion of the eye.

 

  • Vertical lines indicate elevation or depression.
  • Horizontal lines indicate abduction or adduction.
  • Twirling lines indicate the direction of cyclotortion.
  • SR : Superior Rectus       
  • IR :  Inferior Rectus.
  • SO: Superior Oblique.
  • IO: Inferior Oblique.
  • MR: Medial Rectus.
  • LR: Lateral Rectus.

Primary denotes primary muscle action, secondary is secondary muscle action & tertiary is tertiary muscle action

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: In Mini Mental Status examination, maximum score is given for ?
questions.solution:
Maximum score in MMSE (Mini mental status examination ) is given for Orientation.

Mini mental status examination :

 

Feature Score
Orientation 10
Registration 3
Attention/calculation 5
Recall 3
Naming 2
Repeating 1
Following 3 stage commands 3
Written command 1
Sentence writing 1
Copying design 1
  • Total score is 30.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a type of headache under trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia?
questions.solution:
Trigeminal neuralgia is not included under Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias.

The headaches classified under Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias(TAC) include :

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicrania
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks
  • Hemicrania continua
  • Probable trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

TACs need to be differentiated from short-lasting headaches that do not have prominent cranial autonomic syndromes, like trigeminal neuralgia, hypnic headaches, and primary stabbing headaches.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Ballism?

choices.text: Prominent involvement of distal muscles of limbs cause flinging movements
Self injury is commom in these patients

questions.solution:
The prominent involvement of more proximal, not distal muscles of the limbs cause the throwing or flinging nature in case of Ballism.

Ballism :

  • It is the least common of the well-defined dyskinesias
  • Movements of ballism are high in amplitude, violent, and flinging or flailing in nature
  • They are rapid and nonpatterned
  • The prominent involvement of more proximal muscles of the limbs  causes  throwing or flinging nature
  • Self-injury is common and examination often reveals multiple bruises and abrasions
  • Tumor Metastasis is a cause for Ballism

questions.text: Fried egg cell appearance is seen in?
questions.solution:
Fried egg appearance is seen in cases of Oligodendroglioma

Oligodendroglioma :

  • The classic and uniformly accepted oligodendroglial features include :
  • uniformly round nuclei
  • bland chromatin
  • clear perinuclear haloes imparting a “fried egg” appearance
  • rich branching capillary network reminiscent of “chicken wire”
  • Fried egg appearance is a formalin fixation artifact that is neither necessary for diagnosis nor encountered in frozen sections or rapidly fixed specimens.

questions.text: Benton test is used to test?
questions.solution:
Benton Visual Recognition Test is  neuropsychological test that is used to test Memory and Learning.

Neuropsychological tests for testing memory and learning :

Nonverbal/Visual :

  • Benton Visual Recognition Test
  • CMS: Dot Locations, Faces, Family Pictures
  • NEPSY: Memory for Faces, Memory for Designs
  • Rey-Osterrieth Complex Figure, delayed conditions
  • WRAML: Design Memory Picture Memory, Visual Learning

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Phase I of Neuromuscular Blockade by succinyl choline?
questions.solution:
While monitoring the response of phase I of neuromuscular blockade to succinylcholine train of four shows "no fade".

Clinical response  and monitoring of Phase I and Phase II of Neuromuscular blockade by succinyl choline infusion:

 

Response Phase I Phase II
End plate membrane potential Depolarised to -55mV Repolarisation  towards -80mV
Onset Immediate Slow transition
Dose dependence Lower Usually higher or follows prolonged infusion
Recovery Rapid More prolonged
Train of four and tetanic stimulation No fade Fade (post tetanic potentiation follows fade)
Acetyl choline esterase inhibition Augments Reverses or antagonizes
Muscle response Fasciculations leading to flaccid paralysis Flaccid paralysis

questions.text: Autism was described as “enclosure in one’s self” by?
questions.solution:
Autism is a severe neurodevelopmental disorder that was originally described as “enclosure in one’s self” by Leo Kanner in 1943.

It is characterized by three primary features:

  • Impaired language and communication
  • Abnormal or impaired social interaction
  • Restricted, repetitive, and stereotyped patterns of behavior

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is correctly paired with the type of receptor it acts on to exert its antinociceptive effects?
questions.solution:
• Capsaicin transdermal patches or creams reduce pain by exhausting the supply of substance P in nerves and by acting on TRPV1 receptors in the skin.
  • Lidocaine and mexiletine are useful in some cases of chronic pain and act by blocking Nav1.8, which is uniquely associated with nociceptive neurons in dorsal root ganglia.
  • Ziconotide, a voltage-gated N-type Ca2+ channel blocker, is used for intrathecal analgesia in patients with refractory chronic pain.
  • Gabapentin, an anticonvulsant drug, is effective in treatment of neuropathic and inflammatory pain by acting on voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
  • Topiramate, a Na+ channel blocker, is another anticonvulsant drug that can be used to treat migraines.

questions.text: The true statement about gamma rhythm (30–80 Hz) is

choices.text: Seen in an individual who is awake but not focused
May be a mechanism to bind together sensory information into a single percept and action

questions.solution:
The gamma rhythm has been suggested as a mechanism to “bind” together diverse sensory information into a single percept and action, but this theory is still controversial.

Other options:

  • Gamma oscillations at 30–80 Hz are often seen when an individual is aroused and focuses attention on something.
  • In the awake state, corticocortical and thalamocortical networks generate higher-frequency rhyth­mic activity (30–80 Hz; gamma rhythm). 
  • This rhythm may be generated within the cerebral cortex or within thalamocortical loops. 

Beta waves occur during daily wakefulness. They have the high frequency and the low amplitude. Alpha waves occur during wakefulness and periods of relaxation (i.e., during meditation). These waves are slower and have slightly higher amplitude and variability than beta waves
